case_title: Commissioner of Income-Tax, Assam vs Kedarmall Keshardeo

question_1.sub_question_a: Smt. Tribeni Debi was a partner in a representative capacity.
question_1.sub_question_b: The minor, Sri Gobindram Bajaj, was not made a full-fledged partner liable for losses.
question_1.sub_question_c: Smt. Tribeni Debi was not a partner in a dual capacity, and the deed of partnership was not invalid.
question_1.sub_question_d: Smt. Tribeni Debi and her minor son, Sri Gobindram Bajaj, had not been made partners jointly, and their individual shares were not required to be specified.

questions_of_law.question_2: The Tribunal was justified in law in holding that the assessee-firm constituted under the deed of partnership dated February 25, 1953, was entitled to registration and in setting aside the order of the Commissioner under section 33-B of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.
questions_of_law.question_3: The Commissioner of Income-Tax could invoke jurisdiction under section 33-B of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, even after its repeal by section 297 of the Income-tax Act, 1961.

key_findings.minor_status: A minor cannot be a full-fledged partner under section 30 of the Indian Partnership Act.
key_findings.registration_validity: The partnership deed was valid and genuine, and the firm was entitled to registration under section 26-A of the Income-tax Act.
key_findings.jurisdiction: The Commissioner retained jurisdiction under section 33-B of the repealed Income-tax Act, 1922, due to section 297(2) of the Income-tax Act, 1961.

citations: Kalawati Devi Harlalka v. Commissioner of Income-tax (1967) 66 ITR 680 (SC)
Commissioner of Income-tax v. Dwarkadas Khetan & Co. (1961) 41 ITR 528
N. T. Patel & Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax (1961) 42 ITR 224
Commissioner of Income-tax v. Bagyalakshmi & Co. (1965) 55 ITR 660 (SC)
Commissioner of Income-tax v. A. Abdul Rahim & Co. (1965) 55 ITR 651 (SC)
Ram Laxman Sugar Mills v. Commissioner of Income-tax (1967) 66 ITR 613 (SC)
